About Gap Quiz
This quiz has been developed to allow you to test your understanding of a wide range of issues relating to Good Academic Practice. In particular the quiz allows you to demonstrate your awareness of:

•what is meant by the term plagiarism 
 •what is deemed to be acceptable and unacceptable academic practice 
 •how to correctly cite and reference different source material 
 •how good academic practice, including different learning strategies and study skills, can help you to avoid plagiarising other people’s work and so become an effective learner.

The questions are all at an introductory level, which means they are suitable for anyone studying at higher education level. You may find it useful to repeat the quiz at key points in your studies (e.g. before you submit each piece of coursework).

INTRODUCTORY LEVEL: GOOD ACADEMIC PRACTICE QUIZ

There is no limit to the number of times you can attempt this quiz and you will find that the questions change each time you try it. You must leave a gap of a week between each attempt at the quiz. 
 You should submit your answer to each question and read the feedback provided before moving on to the next question. As you complete each question, a coloured bar will appear. Correct answers are shown by a green bar, partially correct answers by an amber bar and incorrect answers by a red bar.

You can have multiple attempts at some questions, but you will lose marks for each attempt at a question that is incorrect.

Use the 'Next' link at the bottom of each question to move to the next question. When you have completed the quiz, click 'Submit all and finish' in order to receive your score and review your answers.

This is an introductory level question on /‘Understanding Turnitin/’

You may be instructed by your Module tutor to submit your coursework online and, if so, you will be required to submit your work into a system called Turnitin. \n Turnitin compares the text of your coursework with a variety of online sources.\n
It produces a report that details the extent to which the text of your coursework has been matched to your own and other people’s previously submitted or published work.

This is an introductory level question on ‘Writing in your own words’.

In this question you will be asked to read an extract from an academic source, followed by an example of a student’s essay in which they have attempted to paraphrase the original academic source. You are to decide whether or not the student has paraphrased the original source in an acceptable manner, as well as followed the correct conventions for citing and referencing it.

Paraphrasing means to put the original source into your own words. It is an important skill to develop as it demonstrates that you have understood, rather than simply reproduced, what you have read.\n The original extract is from an article by Dr. Erik Borg published in The Academic Writer, the journal of The Centre for Academic Writing, Coventry University,

Academic integrity refers to a code of behaviour that is expected of all participants in academic life. Based on the fundamental value of honesty, the expectations associated with academic integrity are not different from those of life outside the academy, and among them are that participants will not cheat, plagiarise, improperly collude, or falsify research findings. \n
Plagiarism is the use of other people\’s language and ideas without appropriate credit. Plagiarism is one of the most challenging areas of academic integrity. \n (Borg 2010: 1).
List of References \n Borg, E. (2010) \‘What is academic integrity?\’ The Academic Writer 1 (1), 1-2

Consider the following extract from a student\’s essay: According to Borg, academics need to uphold the values associated with integrity within the scholarly community, in much the same way as they would in their everyday lives (2010: 1). Although he refers to a range of academic crimes, in particular Borg argues that academics should not plagiarise and that plagiarism is a highly complex issue (2010: 1). The complicated nature of plagiarism will now be discussed in more detail. \n
